The ranch opened to the public as a tourist attraction in 2014. The environmentally friendly ranch raises over 400 cows, 100 sheep and 40 horses. Visitors can easily view the ranch by riding a tractor over the 5-kilometer-long course. The view of the ranch and surrounding area is best seen from the sky deck observatory, located at 1,000 meters above sea level. The ranch also features four themed walking paths. Available activities include horseback riding, and feeding baby animals. ## Intro | | | | - | - | |accomcount:|N/A| |expagerange:|Open to visitors of all ages

data.title: Daegwallyeong Sky Ranch (ëŒ€ê´€ë ¹ í•˜ëŠ˜ëª©ì¥)
data.description: Daegwallyeong Sky Ranch, established in 1974, is located on a 100 million ã¡ plot of land in the highlands of Daegwallyeong Pass. The ranch opened to the public as a tourist attraction in 2014. The environmentally friendly ranch raises over 400 cows, 100 sheep and 40 horses. Visitors can easily view the ranch by riding a tractor over the 5-kilometer-long course. The view of the ranch and surrounding area is best seen from the sky deck observatory, located at 1,000 meters above sea level. The ranch also features four themed walking paths. Available activities include horseback riding, and feeding baby animals.
data.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Phoenix Pyeongchang (íœ˜ë‹‰ìŠ¤ í‰ì°½)
dataList.description: Phoenix Pyeongchang is a famous recreational resort complex comprised of various leisure facilities including ski resort, golf club, condo, hotel, youth hostel, and others.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Phoenix Blue Canyon (íœ˜ë‹‰ìŠ¤ ë¸”ë£¨ìºë‹ˆì–¸)
dataList.description: Phoenix Blue Canyon is a leisure water park that uses pure water from deep valleys amid the fresh air of Gangwon-do. It features Mediterranean-style water facilities, comprised of various resting areas and water rides.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Peace Dam - Hwacheon (í‰í™”ì˜ëŒ (í™”ì²œ))
dataList.description:
Peace Dam in Hwacheon-gun was built in response to a potential flooding attack from North Korea. The first phase of construction began in 1986, and ended in 1989; the second phase, which entailed raising the x_height of the dam, began in 2002, and ended in 2005.

Over the years, the dam has become a major tourist destination. It has several cultural and recreational facilities including the Water Culture Center, an artificial wall stream, and rest areas. It is also located close to the DMZ, and natural landmarks such as Bimok Park, Bisugumi Valley, and Suhari Fishing Site.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Paroho Lake (Yanggu) (íŒŒë¡œí˜¸(ì–‘êµ¬))
dataList.description:
Paroho Lake is a manmade lake that was completed in 1943. The lake was created due to the construction of a hydraulic power plant in Hwacheon during Japanese colonial period. The name was given after President Syngman Rhee designated a plaque in his own handwriting naming the body of water â€˜Paroho Lakeâ€™ during the Korean War after a victorious feat in a battle against the Chinese army. The power plant has a generation capacity of 105,000 kilowatts, and the lake is one of the top fishing grounds in Korea as it is abundant in freshwater fish.

The area boasts several splendid views and a former president built his country home on the lake. Relics from the Stone Age and New Stone Age were found to be well preserved in the area. Twenty-one dolmens were found on the lake grounds, as well as 4,000 pieces of Prehistoric relics used during Paleolithic age, drawing interest from the academic field. Recently, habitats of mandarin ducks, a national natural monument, were found near the Paroho lakeside.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Paroho Lake (Hwacheon) (íŒŒë¡œí˜¸(í™”ì²œ))
dataList.description: Paroho Lake is a manmade lake created when Hwacheon Dam was built in the valley of the Bukhangang River. The lake was once referred to as Daebungho Lake for its resembling image of an imaginary phoenix rising with its wings spread wide open when seen from afar. The area was a territory of North Korea after Koreas independence, but became a South Korean territory after the Korean War.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Pak Kyongni House (ë°•ê²½ë¦¬ë¬¸í•™ê³µì›)
dataList.description: Pak Kyongni House is a place to explore the life and works of  prominent novelist Pak Kyongni. The houses theme was based on Pak Kyongnis well-known novel Toji (The Land).The site used to be her old house before it was converted into a park. Covering an area of 10,578.51 ã¡, the garden and the house have been maintained in their original state. The park also features three themed areas recreated from the book  Hongi Dongsan, Pyeongsa-ri Madang, and Yongdurebeol.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Osaek Mineral Spring (ì˜¤ìƒ‰ì•½ìˆ˜í„°)
dataList.description: Osaek Mineral Spring is situated 20 kilometers west of Yangyang and 7.5 kilometers southeast from Hangyeryeong Pass. The water, which springs from three base rocks by a brook, is carbonated and rich in iron. Up to 1,500 liters of iron-rich water spring out on a daily basis. Osaek became well known due to the splendid landscape leading up to the mineral spring and its location on the way to the summit of Seoraksan Mountain.
dataList.author: korea-tour
